_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Arctic Cold Storage's senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  The facility maintains a Safety Committee whose members are the designated emergency commanders for the facility.   Arctic Cold Storage has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect, which is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained at the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.



Arctic Cold Storage has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration operation and maintenance firm.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Arctic Cold Storage to evacuate and to allow the fire department/HazMat Team to respond to the emergency.  The refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE 



Arctic Cold Storage is located at 4139 Roosevelt Road, in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  The facility is approximately 0.45 miles north of Interstate 94, approximately 3.9 miles east of Highway 15, and approximately 50 feet east of Co. Rd. 75.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of light commercial and industrial areas.  The facility began operations in 1980 and added a second ammonia system in 2006.



The primary business of Arctic Cold Storage is to provi

de cooling and storage of food products. The regulated material present at the facility and the focus of this study is ammonia.  The facility employs two independent refrigeration systems that contain approximately 8,341 pounds (West system) and 10,890 pounds (East system) of anhydrous ammonia each, as a refrigerant within a closed system.  However, the two systems' combined inventory, exceeds 10,000 pounds and the systems are being considered as 'co-located' processes for the purposes of the Risk Management Plan regulation.  The systems, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for dock operations and cooler/freezer storage.  Typical operating conditions range from approximately 8"Hg on the low pressure side of the systems to 145 psig on the high side. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS 



The Arctic Cold Storage ammonia refrigeration systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Arctic cold Storage facility operates in accordance with OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation.  Refrigeration contractors, experts in the ammonia refrigeration industry, are contracted at the facility to maintain the system and perform any repairs.



The Arctic Cold Storage facility including each ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include ammonia sensor in the engine rooms as well as sensors in the cold storage areas, and automatic shut down system  that prevent equipment damage and ammonia releases.  In addition, the majority of the

ammonia inventory is maintained inside the machine room and just outside of the machine room (condensers).  All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation and vent through a common header to the atmosphere.



In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration System."



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its

threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following:



? On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

? Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or

sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



An investigation into the facility's accident history during the PHA study performed on January 26-27, 2016 revealed that there been no releases over the previous five years January 2011 - January 2016) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in 24 hours or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 



Arctic Cold Storage has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility. The Emergency Evacuation and Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 



1.)    To save lives. 

2.)    To minimize and avoid injuries. 

3.)    To protect the environment.

4.)    To minimize property damage. 



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation proced

ures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM/RMP regulations.  



If a release of ammonia were to occur, Arctic cold Storage will determine the extent of the emergency.  The alarms are tied into the ammonia sensors and will automatically alarm.  Arctic Cold Storage management will determine if an evacuation is necessary.  They will call 911 in order to reach the appropriate HazMat Team who will resond to the ammonia release.  Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



A Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation (PHA) was conducted on January 26-27, 2016 to further improve the safety at the Arctic Cold Storage facility in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  The PHA was comprised of one session that included a discussion of any changes to the ammonia refrigeration system since the February 16, 2011 PHA Revalidation, a detailed review of the recommended action items generated during the 2006 Process Hazard Analysis and the 2015 PSM/RMP Three-Year Compliance Audit, a discussion of the facility's accident history dating back five years, completion of industry checklists, a site inspection to review the piping diagrams, review of the worst case and alternative case release scenarios, and review of the RMP*Submit.  The recommended changes from the PHA Revalidation study are scheduled to be completed by January 2017.



In addition, the facility is planning to complete several items over the next year as their continued effort to provide a safe work environment for Arctic Cold Storage employees in St. Cloud, Minnesota.  These changes include the following items:



1.    Continue to train all employees in Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.

2.    Continue to have employee involvement in

updating and refining Process Safety Management and the facility's safety programs.

3.    Continue employee involvement through the Employee Participation program.

4.    Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
